wpPost.title: Building My Portfolio Site and Blog
wpPost.content:
My WordPress blog just wasn’t cutting it. As far as WordPress blogs go, there was nothing wrong with it. I had a portfolio page for my video work and photography. I enjoyed formatting and managing my blog posts with WordPress. It was a fine WordPress blog, but I’m a front end web developer. A personal site built with a WordPress theme just felt a little amateurish. It was time for a redesign.

Designing The Site

In search of inspiration, I scoured Behance for designs that stood out to me. I noticed that many of the designs included extra information, such as font and color descriptions. I could see how this extra information and attractive formatting helped communicate the overall feel of the design. I was excited to put together a design that felt like a product in itself, I also figured it would make for good practice. You can find by final design on Behance.

I wanted to create a site that brought to mind conifer forests and rivers brimming with glacial melt. I was inspired by photos I had taken at Glacier National park couple of years prior. I chose my topography with the parks early 20th century lodge in mind. I was going for something classy, rustic, and timeless. I selected my fonts from Google fonts and used Adobe Kuler to create my color scheme. The design work was done in Photoshop.

The purpose of my personal site was clear. I needed a place to showcase the work I do. The only problem was that I needed to showcase three disparate types of work on one site. This presented a design challenge. How could I display my video work, web development projects, and blog with equal importance while still quickly directing users to what they are looking for. My solution was to treat the homepage as a landing page similar to a link tree. My portfolios and blog can each be accessed via cards on the homepage. They are stacked in a way that gives equal visual importance. Placing the cards in a grid also lends itself to mobile designs because they can stack one on top to the other.

Choosing My Framework

While I was building my site from scratch, I still wanted to use WordPress to write and manage my blog posts. I could have built a custom WordPress theme, but this would have meant writing PHP and building a site that was server side rendered. I was concerned with performance and prefer to work in Javascript. This led me to Gatsby.

What Is Gatsby

Gatsby is a static site generator, but some would say it’s more akin to a modern front end framework. Gatsby sites are written in React, but is deployed as a static site. This circumvents some of the search engine optimization problems that come along with React, and yields all of the security benefits inherent to static sites. Gatsby also uses GraphQL to build its data layer. This means data from multiple sources can be combined into one GraphQL server. After installing the necessary source plugins, data from (for example) markdown and WordPress are queried in the same way. Gatsby is also fast, especially compared to WordPress.

Project Structure

One benefit to using React over plain HTML, CSS and Vanilla Javascript, is that it enables developers to create reusable components. This means portions of code that appear in multiple places (such as a navigation bar) can be written once, stored in it’s own file, and imported into the pages that require it. This makes site maintenance infinitely easier, improves code readability, and makes for a more enjoyable developer experience. Working to keep my code DRY, I created a layout component . Each page calls the layout component and passes the page content to the component. The layout component then generates the page title and tacks on the navigation bar and footer. Because the homepage features a full screen image that the navigation bar sits on top of, I needed to allow the homepage to render the navigation bar on its own. I used conditional rendering to render that navigation bar within the layout component only if the page title is not “Home”. My code is still DRY because the navigation bar is stored in it’s own component.

Organizing My Style Sheet

CSS style sheets are notorious for being difficult to maintain. I wanted to make sure my style sheet would make sense to me when I come back to it months from now. I achieved this by separating my styles into logical sections using comment headings. The top of the document has rules for resetting default styles and color variables. Styles unique to one page sit under a comment header identifying the page they belong to. Sections are loosely laid out based on where they appear on the page. For example, the footer rules are at the bottom of the document just above the media queries.

Using WordPress as a Headless CMS

Because I already had blog posts hosted on a WordPress site, I was eager to dynamically pull posts from my existing blog to my new blog. I was able to do this using GraphQL and the WordPress API. The front end (the head) is built with Gatsby while the back end data is stored in WordPress. This makes WordPress a headless content management system. I’m able to use all of the editing tools native to WordPress while still taking advantage of Gatsby’s speed, security, and enjoyable development experience. It took some fiddling to get the formatting and page routing right, but the final result is an attractive and maintainable blog.

The Jam Session Player

Jam sessions were a series of acoustic live performances I recorded between 2015 and 2017. I wanted to create a custom playlist with a list of videos on the bottom and a video player at the top. I created an array of objects to store information on each video. Each object contains the video title, Youtube ID, and a boolean to denote visibility. I then loop over the array and display the video using React Player. If the visibility property is set to false, the CSS display property is set to none. Below the video player, I display a list of video thumbnails pulled from ytimg API using the Youtube ID. When a user clicks on a thumbnail, the corresponding video’s visibility is set to true and all other video’s visibility is set to false.

Future Updates

In time, there are a few changes I would like to make to my website. I would like to create a gallery component to display my photos. It would allow me to organize photos into separate albums and display the selected album in an attractive grid similar to the Jam Session player described above. The projects on the web development portfolio page are pulled from markdown files for easy updates. I would like to add something similar to the video portfolio page. Finally, my design shows blog post filtering based on tags. Once implemented, users will be able to click on the tag buttons at the top of the blog listing to filter the posts being displayed.
